text:
I don't think you've got your facts straight.

It's quite right that the IPCC wrote that the Himalayan glaciers might melt by 2035, but this assertion was made in AR4, i.e. not in 1990 but in 2007. The IPCC corrected this, and rightfully, as the reference was not a peer-reviewed article but an online post by the WWF. For the claim of 50m refugees, I have never come across such a claim in an IPCC report. Where can I find it?

"Why can't scientist say "I don't know?" it's obvious they didn't accurately predict 30 years into the future 30 years ago. What changed? Why are they better now? There excuse "They were trying to scare us into action." I doubt it, I believe they were simply wrong and don't want to admit it. How can we be sure they are being honest with us now and not again trying to scare us into action."

They never say that they do know; science is rarely about proving. That's why the projections are reported in levels of statistical significance, i.e. likely (p < 0.1) or extremely likely (p < 0.05). And it's why the IPCC has produced 5 ARs and not just one; knowledge is being continuously updated and refined. To that end, we've actually ended up with pretty good models, with most observations being in line with prior projections.

text:
What happened to the link I added/thought I added? Simon here's a video that puts together lots of the facts on livestock reversing climate change, straight to the figures bit https://youtu.be/wgmssrVInP0?t=1075 or earlier to the explanation of how grass with animals on it is doing this better than forests are https://youtu.be/wgmssrVInP0?t=802

That's the link I thought I added before, here's another https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/dec/02/arable-land-soil-food-security-shortage The cause of the degradation of that 40% of agricultural land is 2 things, 
1. replacing animal manure with chemical phosphorous fertlisers and 
2. trying to increase crops grown while decreasing animal time on the land. That's caused by both factory farming of animals and vegan/lowered meat diets. Ethical farmers are now starting to reverse this trend, which means more & more of the food you eat that you think is "vegan" is not anyway, since it's only made possible by the use of fertiliser that comes from farmed animals, but it's also worth noting that mined chemical phosphorous supplies, that are the ONLY option for growing vegan diets are expected to run out within 50 years. They are also the cause of all the farm run off issues that damage rivers, oceans etc. Properly managed grazing animals, or grazing animals/crop rotations of farms simply don't cause chemical run offs & the consequential environmental vandalism.

You also might want to note that rice currently causes 15-20% of human related methane emissions, despite crop land areas being WAY lower than cow grazing land areas. If you were to replace animal farming with rice, the methane production would be astronomically higher than current human induced levels (mind you, that's impossible anyway, most cattle are grazed in semi-arid areas incapable of supporting crop growth, removing them from food production simply shrinks available food production space on the planet

Not a lot of links there, but plenty of info that you can google to see I'm telling the truth when I say vegan diets are incredibly bad for the planet, second only to factory farming

text:
Here's another link for you on "peak phosphorus" (which works the same as peak oil, but is caused by trying to grow grops rather than animals & crops in balance - eg vegan diet or factory farming)
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peak_phosphorus#Phosphorus_conservation_and_recycling "An example of one such crop in South America that takes up large amounts of phosphorus is soy. At the end of its journey, the phosphorus often ends up in rivers in Europe and the USA."
author: Lilac Lizard

text: Locke D   There is no such thing as a global warming denier. It is a strawman argument where people claim they are fairly representing the opinions of others rather than citing what they do say. The idea that climate is invariable is the unacknowledged basis for claiming change is manmade. But change is normal. The amount and kind are not known ahead of time. To say man is causing a disaster is like opinion mongering, something scientists disregard as unscientific. If you can't measure something, you cannot analyze it. Even the idea that radiation calculations determine temperature ignores wind and clouds, seasons, day/night cycles and things like el Nino and the Pacific Decadal Cycle as if other drivers did not matter. We know weather cannot be determined more than a week in advance. To say it can be determined decades in advance is so silly I cannot understand why anyone believes it. To which it is said 'climate is not weather.' It might as well be. Climate consists of patterns of weather. Climate change therefore consists of changes in the patterns of weather.

text: Interesting considering the western Gulf was in the low 80's this year for water temperature while it has been in the mid 80's in the previous recent years.  What actually caused the the amount of rain was that Texas had a very moderate summer and temperatures did not get very high.  There was also very little steering in the atmosphere for the storm so it stalled.  So when a tropical system did push in, the colder air reduced the humidity more.  Same scenario set up for Sandy in New York, except there, the Labrador current is the trigger.  I have a problem with VOX saying "Models".  Models are predictors.  Solid data is what we look at.  Stick to the solid data cause a model with this many variables is a crap shoot.  It's one of the reasons why the hockey stick graph on temperature change is an effective argument for climate change.

Humans say: 

"We're hurting the planet". Nope, the planet is a pretty content ball of magma with a thin layer of rock and a razor-thin layer of water, air and life on top of that. It will be there in a million years, maybe a bit more or less habitable, it doesn't really care...

"But we might go extinct". Maybe. If we really mess up.

But it would be more correct to say that we're threatening economies and civilizations, we're threatening our own convenient lifestyle. Global warming will not kill humanity. Even total nuclear war will most likely not kill all of us. 

It's about whether you prefer to make changes to your life so you can keep living with modern luxuries, or live in a mountain cave and eat rodents & roaches.

author: ASomewhatLongAndMeaninglessUserame

text:
Peter, you're not using your brain. Don't pretend to. Climate change references an intensification of the greenhouse effect, which leads to an imbalance of Earth's energy budget. The specific heat capacity of an object will not lead to the heating of an entire planet; you don't understand basic thermodynamics if you really think so. The amount of energy on Earth‚Äîboth kinetic and potential‚Äîis constant, and only varies based on the amount of energy added from outside sources (notably the sun) or released out of our atmosphere. When our atmosphere gets thicker and the greenhouse effect intensifies, the amount of energy released decreases, leading the planet to get hotter. This is fifth grade science.

You mentioned paint and solar panels. The color white reflects all frequencies of visible light, meaning more energy is reflected away from the surface of Earth; though with a denser atmosphere, this wouldn't help much. Solar panels are highly reflective, and also reflect excess energy away from the Earth's surface and store some of it as potential energy; electricity. The amount of CO2 released by plants in a dark room, even, is too minuscule to affect the amount of CO2 in a room to a level noticeable by humans.

You've yet to substantiate to any degree that any of these things contribute more to climate change than CO2. Don't pull some more garbage out of your ass.
author: Lame Duck

text:
Alexander Jones
Beautiful reply, but I will just correct you on one thing. Solar panels are not 'highly reflective', they're designed to absorb as much energy as possible, not reflect it away. This is why solar panels have an anti-reflective coating, which only allows about 6% of the light to be reflected. It's also what gives them their distinctive deep blue colour.

text:
Peter Gobkoswki
Ok think I can see where your misunderstanding is coming from. You think that because reflective power plants, glass, roads, etc reflect a lot of heat, that heat must be heating the Earth. But this is simply misunderstanding of energy transfer.

A more or less constant amount of thermal solar energy is hitting the planet at all times in the form of infrared radiation. This is Earth's only external source of heating, and so long as the amount of thermal energy being radiated away from Earth is equal to the amount being absorbed, the planet will not heat up. Energy IN = Energy OUT: good. Energy IN > Energy OUT: bad. Since the energy IN is constant, the ONLY thing that matters in this equation is how much thermal energy is being radiated away from our planet. As it turns out, the only thing mediating how much thermal energy is allowed to escape is the atmosphere. Without the atmosphere, Earth would be a frozen, -18 degrees C, floating icicle in space.

The oxygen and nitrogen within our atmosphere are completely transparent to infrared radiation, they do not absorb the heat directly. However, certain molecules in the atmosphere DO directly absorb infrared radiation, namely CO2 (carbon dioxide), H2O (water) and CH4 (methane). These molecules slow heat from escaping out into space by absorbing the thermal energy and emitting it back down towards Earth's surface; acting like a blanket. The concentration of these molecules in the atmosphere directly dictates the temperature of the entire planet. It doesn't matter how many roads or reflective solar farms you build, as they don't prevent heat from escaping, they don't 'trap heat' like the atmosphere does.

text: Man you really need to take some chemistry classes. I'll try to explain why H20 is also greenhouse gas but you should learn about chemistry to have a better understanding. A greenhouse gas is a GAS that contributes to the greenhouse effect by absorbing IR radiation . Conceptually this causes the bonds of the molecule to stretch or bend until eventually the IR radiation is re-emitted back towards the earth essentially trapping the IR radiation within the atmosphere. This is the greenhouse gas effect. Only certain molecules can absorb IR radiation. These molecules have dipoles (difference in charges between atoms) between bonds. This enables the stretching and bending of the intramolecular bonds. H20 has has this dipole and as a result can also absorb IR radiation but, the difference is that H20 can be quickly removed from the atmosphere because it turns into precipitation unlike CO2 which takes a very long time to be removed naturally. Also we are creating a lot more CO2 than H2O.

That's the problem. I've examined hundreds of articles over a period of almost 8 years and fall back on the reasoned analysis a physicist gave me when I started : the case is not made that the models are useful and reasonably complete so as to have an expectation of accuracy. In fact, I was referred to YouTube videos which punched significant holes in pretensions of general scientific acceptance of climate science as a mature and established body of knowledge. Unhappily, over the years I have lost many of my notes - but I still have a catalogue far in excess of any claims of ignorance.
Do not confuse exasperation with hostility. I receive constant citations which I could find by Black's 'debunking of climate deniers' on Grist. author: John Farnham

text:
Can I substantiate either claim? Well yes, I can.

1. The greenhouse effect in exists: The greenhouse effect itself is not a claim, but an absolute fact. The proof is pretty much in the name. Humanity has used greenhouses for centuries. A dome, or 'house', made of glass is significantly warmer on the inside than it is on the outside. This due to the greenhouse effect, hence the name. One can't simply deny the greenhouse effect without being intellectually dishonest.

2. Carbon dioxide causes a greenhouse effect: This fact has been proven time and time again with not only lab experiments and computer simulations, but also with terrestrial and extraterrestrial atmospheric data; one of the most commonly cited being that of venus. I'm sure you've heard the venus argument, so I won't bore you with the details. The fact is, the greenhouse effect (specifically in greenhouses) put simply, is caused because of glass's ability to absorb infrared radiation and re-emit that energy back into the greenhouse; this specific property is similar in carbon dioxide. Hell, you can make carbon dioxide gas sensors based on the amount of infrared radiation absorbed.

text:
I hope you know CO2 doesn't retain heat. It only redirects the IR waves such that more heat is trapped in the atmosphere. 

If you want to understand how the IR energy/radiation is absorbed by you need a bit of chemistry knowledge. Conceptually when a molecule absorbs IR radiation the bonds of the molecule to stretch or bend until eventually the IR radiation is re-emitted  back towards the earth essentially trapping the IR radiation within the atmosphere. This is the greenhouse gas effect. Only certain molecules can absorb IR radiation. These molecules have dipoles (difference in charges between atoms) between bonds. This enables the stretching and bending of the intramolecular bonds.

Quote from nca2014:
" This greenhouse effect is a natural process, first recognized in 1824 by the French mathematician and physicist Joseph Fourier and confirmed by British scientist John Tyndall in a series of experiments starting in 1859. Without this natural greenhouse effect (but assuming the same albedo, or reflectivity, as today), the average surface temperature of the Earth would be about 60¬∞F colder. "

text:
Also if your going to be talking about the sun the nca report has a good response for that:
Could the sun or other natural factors explain the observed warming of the past 50 years? 

 No. Since accurate satellite-based measurements of solar output began in 1978, the amount of the sun‚Äôs energy reaching Earth has slightly decreased, which should, on its own, result in slightly lower temperatures; but the Earth‚Äôs temperature has continued to rise. The sun can explain less than 10% of the increase in temperature since 1750, and none of the increase in temperature since 1960.

Patterns of vertical temperature change (from the Earth‚Äôs surface to the upper atmosphere) provide further evidence that the sun cannot be responsible for the observed changes in climate. An increase in solar output would warm the atmosphere consistently from top to bottom. Warming from increasing heat-trapping gases, on the other hand, should be concentrated in the lower atmosphere (troposphere), while the upper atmosphere (stratosphere) would cool. Satellite measurements and weather balloon records reveal that the troposphere has warmed, and the stratosphere has cooled. This observed pattern of vertical temperature change matches what we would expect from the increase in heat-trapping gases, not an increase in solar output.

Changes in the sun‚Äôs magnetic field are known to affect the intensity of cosmic rays reaching Earth‚Äôs atmosphere and there is some suggestion that this could affect cloud formation; however, observations indicate that the magnitude of this effect is much smaller than the effects from the human-related changes in heat-trapping gases and from particle emissions on clouds and the changes in climate. 

 Large explosive volcanic eruptions can cool climate for a few years after an eruption, if the eruption is powerful enough to send particles far up into the atmosphere. In the atmosphere, sulfur dioxide from volcanoes is converted into sulfuric acid particles that can scatter sunlight, cooling the Earth‚Äôs surface. Particles from exceptionally large eruptions like Mount Pinatubo in 1991 or Krakatoa in 1883 can reach all the way into the stratosphere, where they can stay for several years. Eventually, they fall back into the troposphere where they are rapidly removed by precipitation. Volcanoes also emit carbon dioxide, but this amount is less than 1% annually of the emissions occurring from human activities.

Thus, natural factors cannot explain recent warming. In fact, observed solar and volcanic activity would have tended to slightly cool the Earth, and other natural variations are too small to account for the amount of warming over the last 50 years.
author: Sasquatchan Bearhunter

Ok I think your whole argument can be summarised in these two sentences of yours:

"we are not yet capable of defining reality or knowing the future."
I beg to differ, with the information we've got I think they've been doing a pretty good job of that so far.

"If I want to avoid confirmation bias I need to consider alternative thought."
Yes, of course it is always necessary to consider alternative thought, but when the evidence unequivocally proves the current model and does not support the alternative, the alternative must be rejected as false. When I saw the whole flat Earth thing pop up, sure I mentally rejected it straight up, but I still looked into what evidence they had to support their claims. Turns out they had little to no reasonable evidence, so I was easily able to reject that thought and keep the current model. In summary, yes you should consider the possibility that global warming is not occurring, but when the evidence proves beyond reasonable doubt that it is occurring, you have to accept that. You claim to want to avoid bias, yet you are denying a whole field of scientific study and a whole body of evidence.

text: Your starting arguments badly pummel the idea that averaging is a useful exercise when it comes to drawing  conclusions for a place - which is fine when generalizing is the name of the game. But saying belief dictates everything is spot on. Belief is not knowledge. Therefore is should not be presumed to be such. Therefore the supposed irony in my noting church propaganda techniques are recognized expertise only deflects recognition from seeing that the IPCC is the agency tasked with promoting climate propaganda. In fact, the main thrust of argument about 'climate science' completely avoids whether or not it is worth the powder to blow it to Hell in favour of pursuing techniques to make argument more convincing. But you avoided the unprovable allegation part with skill indeed. Any scenario which has not happened cannot buttress an argument or POV regardless of other considerations. The reason is basic : it has not happened is the best of all reasons for rejecting a proposition - not the worst.
author: John Farnham

text: The IPCC releases position papers to governments. That is their function. Pursuing techniques to make argument more convincing is science alright. Mindwashing has nothing to do with calculating probable futures, however. It is not so much about trusting experts as it is about distrusting people who totally ignore a foundation of scientific method : reasoned respectful discussion. That does not mean agreeing. In fact, consensus is to be avoided. On threads such as these, it is most common to hear what 'deniers' are alleged to believe. What a variety of people consider likely is nowhere to be seen. In fact, it is derided because it is not 'expert.' If there is a better definition of an Echo Chamber emphasizing Confirmation Bias I do not know what it might be.

text: "! It's like the paper you showed me about evapotranspiration cooling Earth, you probably got that from a source claiming it was "proving" something else entirely" Not at all. But I am not privileged to have an organized body of 'knowledge' behind my thoughts where I can dig into a file for a citation. This was not even claimed as fact but as ongoing consideration as a possibility. Rather I must read and see who seems to respect peoples' intelligence and point up where it is not really possible to understand what is happening in the world when there are limits to data, calculation and understanding of processes and cycles perturbing results. Those and rounding errors flummox weather forecasting in a week and augur no better for climate forecasting decades hence. Nor does there seem to be proper acknowledgement of the limitations of process. Progressive analysis which does not respect parameters of data accuracy in coming to conclusions in the first place begs to be dismissed as frivolous regardless of how expert it is claimed to be. That is why the situation with weathermen/meteorologists is instructive. Climate science is not simpler because of scale. It becomes more rather than less complex.
author: John Farnham

text: " the scientist's job towards the public is one of teaching, not one of debating. " "You would be right if we were scientists debating among ourselves, but we are not. " And so it goes. There is no compromise between allegations that everything is perfectly understood and settled and someone who laughs at your presumption and arrogance. It is quite contrary to any sense of humility that  we are not yet gods and our understanding is limited to perceptions available within constraints of time and place and kind.
author: John Farnham

text: " eventually the IR radiation is re-emitted back towards the earth " This is the part that is not at all intuitive with me. I expect radiation to occur in all directions rather than to be focused. And for all the hoo haw about AGW being a science, there are more flat assertions of "science says" available than proofs and measurements of process. Even if the CO2 speculation is correct - and there are diminishing returns in any absorption process - it does not show that countering processes do not exist to make such analysis speculative to virtually irrelevant. Nor should we expect measurements of what happens in closed containers to accurately reflect dynamic processes in an open chaotic system with multiple forces at work. Else meteorologists would not have to be constantly recalculating.
author: John Farnham

text: " The oceans thus release CO2 because higher temperatures lessen ocean life's ability to store CO2." Are you trying to prove you are making this up ? Solubility of CO2 in water is reduced as water heats up. Ocean life has nothing to do with it.
author: John Farnham

text: "freezes at a lower temperature" The way that appears in my feed makes it a non-sequitur - but I'm reasonably sure you should be saying it changes state at a higher temperature.
author: John Farnham

text: "Of course the science seems underwhelming if you don't read the papers talking about this kind of stuff. " Think about it. When would the average person ever read such ? That does not mean that I cannot follow reasoning somewhat if I happen  on comments by various specialists in comment threads. Certainly the field of climate analysis requires input from different disciplines, but that does not mean that synthesis is complete and accurate. It is far easier to claim that study is over than to explain why ongoing study is required in such a case. That is why CSIRO became such a debacle. You cannot simultaneously have a need for study and  belief that it is complete.
author: John Farnham

text: Exactly the problem with the'denier' meme in the first place. In many cases there are as many opinions as there are individuals. There is no hope of putting their thoughts to rest as they are too varied. But I believe it is premature to claim the case has undeniably been made ( especially while claiming disagreement is the province of 'deniers' ). There seems no way to demonstrate that is true. In such a case to say that the truth has yet to be discovered is no more than prudent reservation.

Mounting evidence from correct analysis of raw data that shows on a daily basis, year to year, we are actually cooling and have been doing so for decades.

Compelling evidence that CO2 levels actually trail global temperatures by centuries.

Global cooling does not play well with the anti-capitalist, anti-freedom agenda.

text:
Let me preface this by saying: I don't care who you voted for. Everyone is entitled to their own political beliefs. However, science is not a political belief. And denying climate change is just flat out dangerous at this point. Humans do affect climate change, and there have been plenty of studies to prove this. (I would suggest you google, but https://climateaction.mit.edu/ and https://climate.nasa.gov/ are 2 quick resources.

Here are somethings you can do go promote "greener living." 
If you are young:
Try going vegan, even if its not for 7 days a week. 
Some schools have gardens.
Try talking to your parents about global warming.
Finally, try to reduce your own energy cost.

When you are older:
Vote only for people who are educated about climate change.
Invest in renewable energy, just for your own home.
Fuel-Efficient/Electric cars + Public transport.
And again, reducing your own carbon footprint.

Small food note: Be careful what you buy. Palm oil, is used in a lot of products, and is mainly being supplied from areas that are cutting down rain forests in south america and Africa.

text: I think global climate change is a real thing, but there is the "deniers" side, the "global warming" side, and the truth which lies somewhere in the middle. The warming of the oceans creates bigger storms which cool the atmosphere more. Granted, this is only a minor offset, but it makes a difference. The increase of rainfall from these bigger storms should increase the amount of green ground cover which should lower temperatures and absorb more CO2 if we don't immediately put it back into the atmosphere by burning it or even cutting it down. We may have to see weeds as our friends to combat the problem. There is another benefit from these massive storms; more desalinated water. If we can harness and distribute this bounty, we could save ourselves from our polluted water sources. I don't know how this could happen, but it is a possibility.

author: Lilac Lizard

text:
To Lilac Lizard and Walter

I understand that renewables are becoming successful and growing worldwide (especially in China). But the fact is that we won't be able to ween ourselves off of fossil fuels in time to reduce the effects of climate change. Humans still pump out billions of tons of CO2 every year and there's a delay in the climate system so that even if we stopped today, the climate would continue to warm for some time. 

Don't give up on renewables, we're going to need them. But we need a new focus on shoring up our country's infrastructure and providing help to others. 

Unfortunately, it looks like we aren't doing a lot in that department either. A federal advisory committee to the US Climate Assessment was just dismissed, and their job was to translate climate change data into actionable policies for the private and public sectors. Disappointing.

author: Wex MCL

text:
Anonymous "Maybe we'll figure out how to extract CO2 from the atmosphere by then." um have you looked outside your window? We already know how to do it, it's called plants! 
You are ABSOLUTELY right that infrastructure needs to be built to deal with climate change! Even just at the levels we're seeing today & if we start reversing now, that is still financially sound to do when you look at the damage that occurs everytime a climate change enhanced storm hits an area that hasn't been upgraded to best practice building given current climate change knowledge

Back to fossil fuels/ reversal, lets remember that even if we made a complete switch to renewables today, it wouldn't in anyway reverse anything & like you say there's a lag time, but there's also other carbon releases in progress, in particular destruction of forests & degradation of cropland soils, as their topsoil & fertility is lost, what's actually being lost is  carbon & 40% of the world's croplands are degraded to the point that they can only produce if massive quantities of chemical fertilisers are added to them. These soils had on average 20-30% carbon (the blacker the soil, the more carbon in it) before industrial farming. Most industrially farmed soils now have less than 5% carbon left & the amount keeps dropping! That's a LOT of carbon being released into the air! (around 1 gigaton of carbon a year in America alone right now)

Sounds bad, but it actually has the potential to be VERY GOOD too! There's 5 billion hectares of seasonal grasslands currently on the planet. With properly managed intensive rotational grazing, they can add 1/2-1% carbon back into the soil in 1 year. That's 100 tonnes of CO2 for every hectare managed with Serengeti style rotational grazing (where huge herds of livestock are grazed for a single day on a small section of land, then moved to the next section & so on for a year - each section that gets the large herd for 1 day and is then is allowed to rest until grasses mature sequesters carbon at that rate, after grass maturity, the herd can be brought back in for another day to add another 1% carbon to the soil).

So it's actually possible to return to pre-industrial CO2 levels within around 20 years if half the world's grasslands have this system applied to them. It can be done with large herds of wild ruminants if desired, but farm animals like cows are just as effective & as a side effect produce masses of food & we're talking land that's already available, no trees need to be chopped down or anything & most of the land available is currently suffering desertification & this system also reverses that. Here's a video, linked to the point of the pics showing the impact on desert like land https://youtu.be/vpTHi7O66pI?t=984

We still need to reduce oil & increase renewables, but there ARE financially viable options (low cost to set up & actually increase profits significantly when done), with currently available technology that we can use today to actually start sucking large amounts of Carbon back out of the air to avoid crossing that tipping point. Another video with the numbers & how exactly this can work https://youtu.be/wgmssrVInP0?t=635

text:
Don't be too sure you do Anonymous! lol I was just reading one when a notification of you message popped up & figured I NEED A BREAK FROM READING IT!!!!!! lol it's really heavy stuff & need to read lots of studies (at least with the ones I've found so far) & put them together to really understand it all, the videos are easier cause they've already done all the work :) Anyway here's probably the most concise one I've found so far (although not great on reputability imo, can't see peer reviews of it) http://www.jswconline.org/content/71/2/156.refs (and full text of that one has a link on that page) or the more reputable one I'm reading now http://www.fao.org/fileadmin/templates/agphome/documents/climate/AGPC_grassland_webversion_19.pdf (fao is the UN food security organisation)

The great thing about this system though, as that UN one keeps explaining, is it wasn't even developed to combat CO2 emissions, it was developed to increase production & restore desertifying lands & CO2 sequestration is just a nice side effect of these. There's a lot more documents relating to the impact in that regard (and it's possible to figure out the details on success there, that carbon has to be going into the soil) Here's a couple of links on if the managed intensive rotational grazing actually does what it's primarily claimed to do http://www.grazingbestprac.com.au/research/grazing/AGEE3851%20Grazing%20management%20impacts%20in%20north%20Texas%20v12011.pdf
https://www.tropicalgrasslands.asn.au/Tropical%20Grasslands%20Journal%20archive/PDFs/Vol_34_2000/Vol_34_03-04_00_pp207_218.pdf
Have fun :)

text:
Ok so... the main reason why hurricane Harvey has resulted in so much flooding is mainly because it stalled out and there wasn't anything going on in that part of the atmosphere to move it away from that area. So it's basically a hurricane/tropical storm hovering over the same location for days. Texas is relatively flat so it doesn't weaken storms as quickly as mountainous terrain. However, that being said, hurricane Harvey developed extremely quick (rapid intensification). It basically went from being a disorganized storm to a category 4 monster within 48 hours (maybe a LITTLE more or less, don't quote me on that). This kind of intensification occurred mainly due to the favorable atmospheric conditions and the extremely warm ocean temperatures. So yes, global warming can lead to stronger storms developing quicker due to the warmer seas but the main reason why Harvey was/is so bad was because it stalled out, pouring endless rain on the area not really because of its strength. 

I do agree we need to reduce our carbon footprint and we need to worry about climate change because it is real. There's a lot of different things that make up hurricanes and the damage they do. Harvey is a very special case.

text: Understandably, Nuclear waste is a problem, and scientists would love to solve it, and they almost did. Yucca mountain was an area designated to hold nuclear waste underground and far away from everyone. However, for some reason, the government denied its usage 20 years ago, and now we have little place to put the waste. With this information, two things need to be solved. One, Yucca Mountain (or something like it) needs to be designated by the government to hold this waste temporarily. Two, scientists need to find ways to neutralize or reverse the effects of nuclear waste and perfect the system of creating nuclear energy. The reason this has not happened yet is because the discretionary budget for science was around 31 billion dollars, or 3 percent of the discretionary budget in 2016, which applied to all of science research. And with Trump in office, it would be cut down by 2 billion dollars, or reducing it to 93% of its original amount, which is a major problem to the future of these energy sources. We need more research on the topic of nuclear waste, and the aftermath will be amazing, for the globe and your house. I do agree there is not enough research to make this type of energy completely viable by using nuclear fusion and fission, but the least the government can do is allow these brilliant scientists to research it more in depth.

text:
To all those people who complain of nuclear waste, this can be improved very easily. The biggest problem is that there is little investment into nuclear engineering so almost all the power plants that exist are based upon technology from the 1960s. There are more modern alternatives which produce nuclear waste with shorter half-lifes (In the 100s of years rather than 1000s) and are much more efficient. A good example is liquid thorium reactors.

This is all nicely explained in Kurzgesagt's/In a Nutshell's video on nuclear power

text: First, Lizard, simple fact checks: the 2.4 billion you're talking about isn't just for nuclear. It's for all environmental clean ups, including oil spills and coal. (https://energy.gov/fy-2017-department-energy-budget-request-fact-sheet) Yeah, but the hidden costs behind burning coal are greater for sure than nuclear. And you're talking about the old technology- the fuel rods and water cooling. New reactors encase the radioactive material in ceramic material/ tennis ball sized pellets. If there's a power outage, then they roll into an underground tank. 1) Fission heat can't get high enough to melt the ceramic material. 2) The water used to cool the pellets won't be waste. New nuclear technology can hack it (coal, natural gas, etc), but solar is still better. (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=poPLSgbSO6k&ab_channel=Vox)

text:
Zoe Phin
So all scientists but Jaworowski are corrupt and bought? Let's try to leave malice aside, scientists can change fields during their career, it's more common than you think. If something is not working, they just leave it and go other places. Keeping a massive conspiracy secret is way more difficult than people seem to think.

There's a paper from Etheridge et al. 1996 "Natural and anthropogenic changes in atmospheric CO2 over the last 1000 years from air in Antarctic ice and firn" that takes in account many of Jaworowski objections: they identify where was melting in the record and avoid it, they identify no clathrates and they use different drilling methods and show that there is no effect whatsoever on the concentrations. In fact, Etheridge et al. calculate the uncertainty of CO2 measurements in 1.2 ppm.

I propose that you consider another explanation for the data change: technique refinement. It has been more than 30 years since Neftel et al., and some times people make mistakes. Time passes, people learn and start taking better measurements (from cooler places, better drilling, careful handling, etc). We understand better everything that can go wrong, people (like Jaworowski) voice their concerns and steps are taken to check and minimize the contaminations. We have lowered uncertainty and records from different parts of the world are consistent. We just got better.

Do you have something more recent than 1996 about problems with CO2 measurements in ice cores?

Anyway, the big hint about Jaworowski's work reliability today should be that even denialists trust the CO2 ice core data and accept that CO2 levels have increased since the industrial revolution. They are arguing other things now.
author: Jonathantheweirdo

text:
Jonathantheweirdo,
Uhuh, this is the "newer is better" argument. What you meant to say was that these scientists found politically incorrect results, so they decided to never report higher results for their subsequent studies.

"In presenting measurements of CO2 concentrations in the pre-industrial ice core from Byrd Antarctica, Neftel, et al., in 1982 showed maximum values of up to 500 ppmv. In 1988, the same authors published measurements for the same section of the Byrd ice core, but left off the high readings previously published, reporting a high of 290 ppmv, in agreement with the global warming theory.

Until 1985, the published CO2 readings from air bubbles in pre-industrial ice ranged from 160 to about 700 ppmv, and occasionally even up to 2,450 ppmv. After 1985, the high readings disappeared from the publications! To fit such a wide range of results to the anthropogenic climatic warming theory, which was based on low pre-industrial CO2 levels, three methods were used: (1) rejection of high readings from sets of pre-industrial samples, based on the credo: ‚ÄúThe lowest CO2 values represent the best CO2 concentrations in the originally trapped ice‚Äù, (2) rejection of low readings from 20th century samples; and (3) interpretation of the high readings from pre-industrial samples as representing the contemporary atmosphere rather than the pre-industrial one.

Pearman, et al. ‚Äúon examination of the data,‚Äù rejected 43 percent of the CO2 readings from Law Dome, Antarctica core, 39 percent of the CH4 [methane] readings, and 43 percent of the N2O [nitrous oxide] readings, because they were higher or lower than the assumed ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù' values.

Leuenberger and Siegenthaler claimed that their data from a Greenland ice core demonstrate that the present level of N2O in the atmosphere, 310 ppmv, is an effect of a recent 19 percent increase caused by industrial activity. To reach this conclusion, they rejected 27 percent of the samples with N2O readings deemed to be ‚Äútoo high‚Äù for pre-industrial ice.

Etheridge et al. claimed that their ice core results show a pre-industrial N2O concentration of 285 ppbv. This value was calculated after rejection of 44 percent of their measurements! From the remaining analyses, the high readings from the 16th and 17th century ice, ...which were higher than 20th century samples,...were again eliminated without explanation."

Your scientists are dishonest. You're not going to convince me. Your only argument will be simply to reassert that "older data was wrong, so the scientists had to fix it", i.e. a rationalization for fraud to reaffirm your bias.

The technique itself will determine how much co2 they find. The "new" technique is actually more dishonest than the old. Don't fall for the newthink fallacy.

author: Zoe Phin

text:
Look at Beck's graph. From 1950s (since we have accurate measurements, using the same method accounting for the atmospheric background, over a long period of time), the graph is totally precictable with a slowly rising increase over time. Then, in the whole part of the graph before 1950, suddenly strong fluctuations like an increase from 310 to 420 ppm between 1920 and 1945. So either, the concentration of CO2 levels coincidencentally decided to suddenly stablized to an extremely predictable pattern, of course just in the same year the new method was used for the first time systematically, or Beck's data was extremely flawed due to to obsolete method that was used to aquire them. 

In 1950, the CO2 concentration was around 315. If you continue the trend backwards (and you can do that very well because the curve is so consistent), you end up with around the same numbers obtained from ice core samples (around 280). It's not a proof (there is no actual proof in science), but if results obtained by completely different methods indicate the same results, it's a very strong indication that they are correct.

And of course Beck had no explanation for the extreme fluctations before 1950 opposed to the extremely predicatable pattern that followed. There seem to be no major natural events that would explain any of them.

Yes, the IPCC was founded in 1988, but as so often with the UN, their power was very limited. It took a lot of convincing in the general population in order to make climate change an issue that was actually tackled in politics.

text:
How can it be about science ? What we have is climate fiction instead of general science fiction. The difference is that the story has to be plausible according to known science. Instead, what we have are allegations of established climate science amidst a dogfight saying it is bullshit and bafflegab. Political orientation stories confirm this is the way people are looking at this - rhetoric and tricks running roughshod over any realization that more is at stake than panic over climate and/or weather. Weathermen/meteorologists know weather cannot be predicted accurately much more than a week. Rounding errors and convection effects from rain or snow are not just transient affairs. They change conditions and readings. And then there is the matter of barometric pressure. Where I live there are strong winds from the mountains which would wreck any presumption the sunshine available determines temperature values - though certainly seasons change due to angle of incidence and and hours of daylight. But I am supposed to be concerned about CO2 when it has always tracked temperature as a consequence rather than a cause.
What do scientists say ? Mostly they STFU because they have jobs to protect. But if the answers are known, why do we need researchers ? But they are not. Really. There is just a lot of ratchetjawing that conversation and contention are passe. If that is the case - so is science.

text:
Lilac Lizard Yeah and we can harness it with much more pollution, expense, larger area, less efficiency, etc..

Solar is nice for individuals to put on their roof.. it's completely moronic to use as a large scale replacement for more reliable methods like nuclear which can produce far more power in a smaller area, 365 days a year, with LESS pollution.
author: Eileen the Crow

text:
+Eileen the Crow
"Solar is nice for individuals to put on their roof" but moronic large scale?
Are you aware, that large scale installations are way cheaper than roof top installations?
A significant part of the cost of solar is the installation, which is easier/faster/cheaper when you do it in a big dedicated plant instead of on small units on a roof top.
Now I agree that it is nice for the roof, as that is unused space otherwise, but it is the more expensive solar option.

Regarding the replacement of big scale power plants, the issue is that many big scale power plants have to be replaced anyhow as they are old.
In Germany (German here) we have/had issues to finance replacement power plants due to the big price tag. We have 7 large coal power plants that are getting build, but most investors jump the ship, so right now it looks that not one will be finished.
Looking at nuclear, every German nuclear power plant is old and was build with the help of government support.
author: Jakob Schulze

text:
Eileen, you do realise don't you that the DOE spends 10% of it's annual budget on the clean up of Hanford? (that's a former Nuclear energy site that's been closed for over 30 years if you don't know - and also "the most polluted location in the Western Hemisphere" yes that title goes to a nuclear site not a solar one!) I'm pretty sure $2.4 billion a year could be FAR more efficiently used in solar than it is in the clean up of the contamination that Nuclear energy creates!  Even just the $1.5 billion spent on compensation for workers that have become sick from toxic exposure at that site would go a long way in solar & wind development!

How about you do something about the 56million gallons still at that leaking site before suggesting creating more waste! So far only 1 million gallons has escaped from that facility, time to move the remaining 56 million gallons somewhere safer! 

While you're at it, how about you find a home for America's other 74,000 tonnes of spent nuclear fuel rods! Remember all of this is currently sitting in unsecured temporary pools around the country, much of it along the coasts in areas likely to be impacted by more & more storms as global warming increases, including the one in the current Hurricane affected area, oh & the one one right on the fault line in California would be nice to address too wouldn't it!

Do you even realise that 1/3rd of all Americans live within 50miles of high level nuclear waste?

After you've cleaned up the current mess, THEN we can talk nuclear as if it's not the worst possibly form of mass energy man's ever created! But until that time, lets stop pretending America's not creating the biggest ticking time bomb ever known to the planet! 

If 1 million gallons causes $2.4 billion a year in clean up for over 30 years & no end in sight, how much do you think it's going to cost long term if you don't find a permanent home for the other 74,000 tonnes of spent rods????? Find a home for that stuff or STOP SUGGESTING ADDING MORE TOXIC WASTE TO THE PILE!

author: Zealot

text:
+Dragon Curve Enthusiast
Yes, but there is actually more potential with other elements (like thorium) and there is a lot of uranium/plutonium that we can get in the future from sourced that are unreasonable today (like with gas and fracking).
But overall it is true, that we just push the issue into the future.
Renewable energy will be the future the only question is when will we switch.

And renewables and nuclear are very bad partners, as one needs a centralized grid, while the other prefers a spread out one. And both are very inflexible, with most nuclear power plants needing days to weeks after a shut down to run again.
author: Jakob Schulze

text:
+Zealot62100
Nuclear fusion is very different to nuclear fission and has fewer issues, but is still in development and we don't know if we will ever be able to use it in a proper power plant.

Renewables + energy storage is something we know that works.
(Like electricity to gas for example)
author: Jakob Schulze

text: We would actually achieve fusion much faster if only the fearmongering around nuclear could stop for a moment, energy storage for the grid is still far away as well, fusion could be enough to sustain the world's needs for thousands of years. As for fission, the newest generations of reactors are much more efficient and safe and they could be a decent way to transition towards renewables but we need to be pragmatic for a moment: renewables and energy storage technologies are simply not ready yet and we need to reduce out CO2 emissions *now*, nuclear is our best short-term solution.
author: Zealot

text:
Zealot, if you were addressing the nuclear waste issue, you wouldn't have as much "fearmongering" would you! It's not "fearmongering" when there's a SERIOUS problem that you haven't addressed! Fix the waste problem so he DOE's budget doesn't have to be diverted to the clean up of your unsustainable source & then you can move forward & be taken seriously! Right now nuclear lobbyists are basically saying "it's cheaper because we just hand off all OUR waste problems to taxpayers who aren't even benefiting from our product, but that way we can make more money for shareholders" Let the government pay the $2.4BILLION a year clean up costs!

& you might want to take a look at South Australia and Elon Musk if you are so naive as to think "renewables and energy storage technologies are simply not ready yet". You're being ridiculous to suggest nuclear technology is closer than renewables!

Lets also remember geothermal has barely started to be explored and again has FAR more short/medium future potential than nuclear and gravity water systems have been available for a LONG time as alternatives to batteries and have been integrated into major power stations for decades because of their ability to ramp up & down in seconds in response to demand. Nuclear can't come close to existing green technologies - at least not until you resolve the half century old issue of disposal of 74,000 tonnes of spent fuel rods!
author: Lilac Lizard

text:
+Zealot62100
"the newest generations of reactors"
Which are you talking about, everytime I hear this argument, people tell me about concepts where the technogoly isn't ready yet.
"fusion could be"
Yeah and the key word here is COULD.
Difference to renewable+storage is, that with fusion, we have to develop the technology and then build the powerplants. With renewable and storage we have the technology and just have to build it. Of course both can still be improved, but we know the technology, while fusion is still in development.

"we need to reduce out CO2 emissions *now*, nuclear is our best short-term solution."
Not sure if we are talking about the same. Most new nuclear power plants are way over budget and need 5-10 years to be build. Solar/wind are much faster and easier build, but have a storage issue.

"nuclear...way to transition towards renewables"
But like I said those are very bad partners. In China they build hydroelectrick pumpstations next to nuclear power plants to regulate demand, cause nuclear is good if it runs 24/7, but shitty if you have to turn it off and on.

Gas turbines are much better partners (and are cheap and quickly build) and gaspipelines(infrastructure) can safe gas (produces from reneables) for many month, which makes gas a great additional storage, and that technology doesn't has to be invented like fusion, but just has to be build.
author: Jakob Schulze

text:
Mark Oliver Walsh No. Nuclear is cheaper. 
Nuclear costs $0.02 kWh compared to solar which costs $0.12 kWh.
author: General G. S. Patton

text:
+Zealot62100
Also a little example:
you pay around 4$/watt to build a nuclear power plant while you pay 1.5$/watt for utility solar, while it is predicted, that the price for nuclear will go up, while the price for solar will drop below 1$ by 2020 (continuing the trend of the last years).
Solar has a capacity factor of 15-30%, while nuclear has one of 75-95%, that means that every watt installed in solar, delivers around 1/4th of that delivered by nuclear.
So just based on installation cost, the cost is almost the same (or will reach that price tag in the next 2-3 years.

Now with solar you have close to no running or fuel cost, while for nucelar you have low fuel, but significant running cost.
So just based on that little calculation, nuclear doesn't make much sense economically. Especially when you look at the near future.
Oh and I didn't even touch the topic of cost of the nuclear waste, an issue like with fusion, which isn't solved yet. (Now the recycling of solar is also an issue that still isn't solved, but seems to be easier than that of nuclear waste, which has been an issue for many decades)
author: Jakob Schulze

text: General, is that cost with or without that $2.4 BILLION EVERY year that the DOE is paying for the cleanup of Hanford? If you don't include clean up costs, your cost figures are nonsense! 10% of the DOE's ENTIRE operating budget is diverted to nuclear clean up that the energy companies are refusing to pay! There's better ways to do socialised energy than nuclear clean up!

text:

Those numbers are not for new installations, but for old ones.
In the past nuclear was much cheaper, while solar was much more expensive than today.
Oh and nuclear is exempt from some cost, which is paid by tax payers and not included in that price.

text:
Alex Schmidt,
The sensitivity is much lower. The problem with the IPCC and mainstream climatology is that they are flat-earthers and gravity deniers.

"Adding to the list of scientists and mathematicians who have disproven conventional greenhouse gas theory, Russian physicists OG Sorokhtin, GV Chilingar, and LF Khilyuk noted in their book Global warming and global cooling. Evolution of climate on earth. Developments in Earth & Environmental Sciences (Elsevier 2007) that conventional greenhouse theory is not based on sound physical derivation, with most calculations and predictions based on intuitive models using numerous poorly defined parameters and unproven positive feedback forcing from CO2. Most conventional interpretations and models, such as those of the IPCC, consider only one component of heat transfer- radiation- to create a flat earth radiation budget of the atmosphere, ocean, and land masses, and do not adequately address the impact of e.g. convection and circulation on a rotating sphere. In contrast, the Sorokhtin et al adiabatic theory considers earth as an open, dissipative system that can be described by non-linear equations of mathematical physics, taking into account the formation of stable thermodynamic structures in each compartment, between compartments, and ruled by strong negative feedbacks (e.g. convection, water cycles, clouds). They devised a model based on well-established relationships among physical Ô¨Åelds describing the mass and heat transfer in the atmosphere and subsequently published the paper Cooling of Atmosphere Due to CO2.

The main conclusions of this work are:

1. Convection accounts for approximately 67% of the total amount of heat transfer from the Earth's surface to the troposphere, the condensation of water vapour for 25% and radiation accounts for only 8%. As the heat transfer in the troposphere occurs mostly by convection, accumulation of CO2 in the troposphere intensifies the convective process of heat and mass transfer, because of the intense absorption of infrared radiation, and leads to subsequent cooling and not warming as commonly believed.

2. The analysis indicates that the average surface temperature of the earth is determined by the solar constant, the precession angle of the planet, the mass (pressure) of the atmosphere, and the specific heat of the atmospheric mixture of gases. 

3. If the nitrogen‚Äìoxygen atmosphere of the earth would be replaced by a CO2 atmosphere with the same pressure of 1 atm, then the average near-surface temperature would decrease by approximately 2.5 ¬∞C and not increase as commonly assumed. 

4. The opposite will happen by analogy if the CO2 atmosphere of Venus would be replaced by a nitrogen‚Äìoxygen atmosphere at a pressure of 90.9 atm. The average near-surface temperature would increase from 462 ¬∞C to 657 ¬∞C. This is explained easily by observing how the results of the derived formulas are affected, considering that the molecular weight of CO2 is about 1.5 times greater and its speciÔ¨Åc heat 1.2 times smaller than those of the earth's air. 

5. If the CO2 concentration in the atmosphere increases from 0.035% to its double value of 0.070%, the atmospheric pressure will increase slightly (by 0.00015 atm). Consequently the temperature at sea level will increase by about 0.01¬∞C and the increase in temperature at an altitude of 10 km will be less than 0.03¬∞C. These amounts are negligible compared to the natural temporal Ô¨Çuctuations of the global temperature."

text:
'Alex Schmidt',  Well, I would certainly disagree with the assertion that the climate is less sensitive than expected, based on what I've seen, and I'd be happy to discuss; but regarding the establishment of the temperature record, you said, 'My point is that the climate changes, and it changes from place to place. This makes it hard if not nearly impossible to get an accurate account of the global temperature.'

Your statement here requires qualification.  Please, share your evidence that the data is not enough to demonstrate the global warming we're discussing and address the diversity of attempts to measure climate around the world, like the ARGO program, for example, with its thousands of swimming devices.  There are many different countries contributing data to determine the global record, derived independently from different perspectives.

You also say, 'I'm also not suggesting the planet isn't warming as it is and there's no doubt about that. And to a very small degree we have an influence on that.'

What's your evidence that we can only influence the climate to 'a very small degree'?

text:
Hold on Alex.  There is a lot to disprove here.  I don't know if you are a denier or if you are trying to defend them but, I can certainly prove my point with facts.  I assume you are a well educated person and I'm not trying to attack, I just think your position on climate change is stupid.  I saw that one of the articles you posted on the 97% argument was published by friends of science.  After doing some research, it is clear to see that the organization is largely funded by fossil fuel corporations and lobbyists, and could easily be disproved as a bias and inaccurate source of information.  Here is a link to prove my point.  http://www.sourcewatch.org/index.php/Friends_of_Science     You use friends of science 3 times in your argument.

It should also be noted that most of these websites are written by climate change deniers and are not legit sources of information.  When you try to prove your point, use unbiased articles where nothing but the facts are presented.  Let the reader form their own opinion rather than it be skewed by a bunch of manipulative, liars who change the facts in order to suit their own interests.

The only article written by a legitimate source would be the one by NASA where they talk about antarctic ice.  If you bothered to read the article, you would find that it talks about a one off report showing that antarctic ice is not losing but gaining mass.  Keep in mind that this finding goes against the majority of reports written by NASA scientists.  But, if we were to say that this finding was true, its publisher, Jay Zwally, states that the process would reverse in a few decades.

Alex, I'm not using my feelings here, just the facts.
author: Ryan Hachey

text: Alex, I was trying to point out that the articles you brought to me were biased towards your opinion. Furthermore, I was saying that some of the articles were funded by corporations and people that would benefit from having climate change be ignored.  To me at least, that disproves their credibility as trustable sources and can't really be used towards proving a point.  Also, If you can provide me proof of NASA skewing their data and being sued, I might change my opinion about their credibility too.  And even if they weren't credible, why did you include them in your argument if you already knew they weren't trustworthy in the first place?  Now, here's a link to an article from a non-profit, non-partition website explaining 2 peer reviewed studies that completely contradict your stance on climate sensitivity.  https://insideclimatenews.org/news/05072017/climate-change-science-denial-arguments-rick-perry-red-team-peer-review

text:
223Drone,
about desmogblog
"In an iconic twist of irony the website funded by a convicted money launderer attempts to smear respected scientists and policy analysts who disagree with them as "funded by fossil fuel companies". Intellectually dishonest individuals who are incapable of accepting the existence of scholarly papers contrary to their alarmist ideology have chosen to smear the highly credentialed scientists who authored these papers with libelous ad hominem attacks - falsely implying they are corrupt. No remote evidence has ever been presented that shows a skeptical scientist has changed their position on an issue due to a funding source. While honest investigations have shown these attacks to be baseless: Are Skeptical Scientists funded by ExxonMobil? The problem with the corruption argument is that it implies that scientists and researchers who rely primarily on public funding for their climate work are not motivated to tailor their research to the beliefs and policy views of their funding sources. Yet, policy analyses have shown that public funding of science may be susceptible to producing biased results. Regardless, to claim a largely uncoordinated grassroots movement of skeptical scientists are winning the debate against a highly organized climate monopoly that has received over $79 billion in funding because they were granted a paltry $2 million a year from companies like Exxon-Mobil is beyond laughable.

The Truth about DeSmogBlog

"DeSmogBlog is a smear site founded by a scientifically unqualified public relations man, James Hoggan and funded by a convicted money launderer, John Lefebvre. The irony here is their favorite tactic is to attempt to smear those they disagree with as funded by "dirty money". Since its creation in 2006 the site has done nothing but post poorly researched propaganda with a clear intent to smear respected scientists, policy analysts or groups who dare oppose an alarmist position on global warming. Their articles frequently reference unreliable sources such as Wikipedia and Sourcewatch since they are unable to find any fact based criticisms of those they attack in respected news sources. They have even been caught editing Wikipedia to create their own material to cite. Sure, Wikipedia may delete it, but they can always claim "Oopsy".

text:
Okay Alex, Lets start at the beginning. What exactly is the global warming problem?

- Issues with food security.
- Ocean acidification.
- Refugee migration due to sea level rise.
- Damage to our natural environment.
- Species extinction.
- Floods.
- Droughts.
- Heatwaves.
- More extreme weather patterns.
- Loss of coral reefs.
- Oceanic anoxic events.
- Property loss due to sea level rise.
- Plus the fact that CO2 we emit into atmosphere is to a large extent irreversible.

The following ice core chart shows what CO2 has done in the last 800,000 years. Keep in mind that modern humans have only been around for about 200,000 years. The latest CO2 reading is 406ppm which is well outside limits of what it has been in the last 4 million years.
www.iceandclimate.nbi.ku.dk/images/images_research_sep_09/EPICA_with_current.PNG

Sunlight passes through our relatively transparent atmosphere to warm the Earth. Infrared is reradiated back to space. Some of it is absorbed by greenhouse gases in the atmosphere and reradiated back to the surface. Greenhouse gases in our atmosphere keep the Earth warm at around 15¬∞C. Without an atmosphere, average global temperatures would be -18¬∞C.

Greenhouse gases that are most relevant are Water vapor, CO2, Ozone & Methane. CO2 lets most incoming radiation pass through, but absorbs a significant wavelength of outgoing infrared radiation.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greenhouse_gas#/media/File:Atmospheric_Transmission.png

Natural factors such as total solar input, volcanic eruptions, Milankovitch cycles or cosmic rays do not explain the recent warming, but CO2 does.
https://qph.ec.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-9e97f9181362bc92cce499fb5d487724

Average global temperatures are rising:
www.climate.gov/maps-data#global-climate-dashboard

Sea levels are rising:
https://climate.nasa.gov/vital-signs/sea-level/

Glaciers are retreating:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Retreat_of_glaciers_since_1850#/media/File:Glacier_Mass_Balance.png

Arctic sea ice is receding:
https://climate.nasa.gov/vital-signs/arctic-sea-ice/

The CO2 we put into the atmosphere is to a large extent not reversible. A significant percentage of what we emit will persist in atmosphere for tens of thousands of years. This is not a path we want to go down.
https://petermo.files.wordpress.com/2009/02/solomon-et-al-irreversible-change-f1large.jpg?w=500&h=980

CO2 levels absolutely can lag temperature. CO2 levels also lead temperature changes:
https://skepticalscience.com/co2-lags-temperature.htm

Are you willing to bet it all that CO2 is not a problem? Really? You'd put at risk your future, your planets future, your children's future. That doesn't make sense. Even if there was a small chance of major disaster, any normal person would take action to eliminate or mitigate massive risk.

author: John Farnham

text: You should be aware of the effects of UNESCO upon international academic standards, including comment. If we go back to Climategate for a moment, Michael Mann et al were working out of a facility dedicated to the study of climate change. The thing was, the first 2 directors at East Anglia had no truck with the idea that man controlled weather. By today's meme, they were both 'deniers'....which would be denying the job was over and all inputs were known, explained, charted, etc., etc. That was the reason for Judith Currie's abandoning the teaching of speculative fiction...and Denis Rancourt as well. There are many more examples. The impairment of free discussion is international and political. What all scientists agree on is that people ought to be able to see that firing people who do not agree with you or pressuring them to accept doctrine has no part in the evolution of real science and discovery. In fact, the converse is the case.
author: John Farnham

text: If you were to take note of comment threads at places like Tallbloke's Talkshop the idea that intelligent dissent does not exist would be blown out of the water. Why would I put academic papers up when I am without formal academic credentials ? I simply share discoveries of another kind, not needing to reinvent the wheel and not interested in swallowing whole background of ideas which are innately unprovable. That does not mean I do not enjoy essays on theoretical physics written for the layman, but obfuscating nonsense via mathematical analysis and modeling exercises does nothing for the vapid nature of the basic premise. Repeatedly you will see notes AGW requires atmospheric hotspots as part of the process. They do not exist.

To Beastinlosers

So to boil down the question you're asking.

Do you want issues now? Or do you want issues later on?

The issue with dumping nuclear waste in "some mine from the 1800's", is that the area isn't secure. The waste will inevitably spread. That, and we'll eventually run out of said mines. Nuclear power isn't a sustainable option, just like burning oil/gasoline in our cars isn't.

Nowhere in the comments have I stated that we need to fix this all at once. What I am stating is that we're always talking about what we've done to the planet, not what we can do to prevent further harm. 

Nobody is talking about how expensive it'll be to fully replace all gas burning cars across the planet with electric ones. Nor are they talking about how expensive it will be to maintain and power said electric cars in third world countries.

text:
AShadowWolf "decreasing your carbon footprint" is a noble but pointless objective. If we stop emitting carbon all at once tomorrow, the Earth and its climate will continue to be burdened with greenhouse emissions for centuries. In addition, one's actual carbon footprint is often much more complex then one realizes - you need to take into account transportation, electricity, where your food is grown, what you order online, and where the zippers on the jacket of one of your food providers came from - was it made of iron harvested from the Earth, or was it recycled? It's all to complex too even address, and you don't even receive the desired outcome.

The biggest solution now would be to investigate ways of physically removing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and pray that there is one, because the alternative is that we find a new planet or all die by this century's end, and that's definitive no matter how many vegan meals you have.

text:
Part of the problem is that we‚Äôve been victims of a campaign of systematic misdirection. Consumer culture
and the capitalist mindset have taught us to substitute acts of personal consumption (or enlightenment) for organized political resistance. An Inconvenient Truth helped raise consciousness about global warming. But did you notice that all of the solutions presented had to do with personal consumption‚Äîchanging light bulbs,
inflating tires, driving half as much‚Äîand had nothing to do with shifting power away from corporations, or stopping the growth economy that is destroying the planet? 
Personal emissions, water management, municipal waste, and consumer energy consumption are negligible. The second problem‚Äîand this is another big one‚Äîis that it incorrectly assigns blame to the individual (and most especially to individuals who are particularly powerless) instead of to those who actually wield power in
this system and to the system itself. Kirkpatrick Sale: ‚ÄúThe whole individualist what-you-can-do-tosave-the-earth guilt trip is a myth. We, as individuals, are not creating the crises, and we can‚Äôt solve them.‚Äù

author: Miguel Hernandez

text:
Miguel, plants remove 8% of the planet's CO2 every year. Without animals producing it, the entire CO2 of the planet would be depleted within 15 years! (well not actually, because once the levels drop too low the plants start to die & stop sucking it up, not to mention O2 levels rise, which means more fires that release it back out of the trees again) remember 97% of all organic matter on the planet is plant life. We all have "plant blindness" but plants are already removing it in a natural cycle with animals adding it.

1 hectare of the Serengeti absorbs 100 tonnes of carbon from the atmosphere every year. There's 5 billion hectares of similar land on the planet, all of it capable of sucking the carbon back out at that rate if we simulate the Serengeti with any ruminant animals (including cows, sheep etc that we farm for meat). Check out holistic grazing or managed rotational grazing. It's actually very easy and cheap to reverse the levels (but also drops profits for those currently selling chemicals etc to factory farms and vegans don't like it, so both sides are attacking the idea). If we all demand any meat we eat is grass fed and grass finished, this WILL happen automatically from there.

text:
Global Warming is happening.

The current warming trend is of particular significance because most of it is extremely likely (greater than 95 percent probability) to be the result of human activity since the mid-20th century and proceeding at a rate that is unprecedented over decades to millennia.

Earth-orbiting satellites and other technological advances have enabled scientists to see the big picture, collecting many different types of information about our planet and its climate on a global scale. This body of data, collected over many years, reveals the signals of a changing climate.

The heat-trapping nature of carbon dioxide and other gases was demonstrated in the mid-19th century. Their ability to affect the transfer of infrared energy through the atmosphere is the scientific basis of many instruments flown by NASA. There is no question that increased levels of greenhouse gases must cause the Earth to warm in response.

Ice cores drawn from Greenland, Antarctica, and tropical mountain glaciers show that the Earth‚Äôs climate responds to changes in greenhouse gas levels. Ancient evidence can also be found in tree rings, ocean sediments, coral reefs, and layers of sedimentary rocks. This ancient, or paleoclimate, evidence reveals that current warming is occurring roughly ten times faster than the average rate of ice-age-recovery warming.

Source NASA: https://climate.nasa.gov/evidence/ (read more)

This shows how little you understand when we talk about climate change. a cloud covering the sun causing it to be colder "beneath" is a relative temperature change not a global one. despite the global temperature changing in one direction we can have regions decreasing in temperature and other regions increasing. to the best of my knowledge no one is denying that nor that there are things that influence temperature relative to regions.

But were talking about a net increase in energy i.e. heat on earth. so either the input (mainly the sun) is increasing or the output is decreasing. the sun doesnt adequately explain the net temparature increase which sugests it is the output decreasing. the main factor is greenhousegases, mainly CO2 which through out earths past has regulated the temperature of earth and without any of the ghg much of earth would be frozen like mars. It is true that water vapor is one of the largest contributing greenhouse gases but it has been shown to be a feedback process and cant by itself provide the greenhouse effect on earth.

also are you claiming radiation of heat is not a thing? i hope youre not. to illustrate radiation through something you might have experienced imagine a hot piece of metal or any other object everywhere around it the temperature increases(if the temperature of object is higher than the suroundings) as heat radiates from it. It is the reason you get burned when you hold something hot because heat radiates from objects. same thing goes for earth. now if there werent any greenhouse gasses all of the radiated heat from earth would just escape to space but because there are greenhousegasses some of the radiated heat from earth is radiated back to earth increasing the global temperature.

Again i think youre getting confused by relative temperatures in regions (which can be affected by winds, relative angle to the sun, clouds and many more factors that i dont know of im sure.) and earth temperature as a whole i.e. the combined current energy of earth.
author: mark

text:
Evaporative cooling to space is at best a hypothesis. However, thunderheads have a wild  vertical wind shear and are proposed as a mechanism which would see some molecules escape the atmosphere. Since warm air rises - and the ocean's heat warms the air above the coast at night and in winter - there should be no shock in realizing a) convection transports heat  b) calculations of temperature on other planets are made by calculating the effects of air pressure : not which gases are present.
The idea we can calculate the heat balance of the planet is complicated by things like the thermocline, ocean currents, and the obvious silliness of thinking the depths are going to be warmed by radiation. For all that, vulcanism is ignored as a contributory factor. Yet the warming of the Arctic started in December a while back. That is as in the start of winter in pitch black. Solar gain is not a plausible mechanism. The University of Guelph ran a paper a while back scoffing at the idea of an average planetary temperature as being incalculable. On a planet with temperature cycles I have little respect for representations that people blaming man for change know what they are talking about. Nor have I seen evidence that they can justify their position by calculations. Otherwise the IPCC projections would not be such dog poop.
author: John Farnham

text: I have a problem with using averages to calculate normal variation. It just does not sound to be helpful in analysis although trend lines can be projected - an idea made somewhat problematic by choice of endpoints and effects of ENSO and PDO ocean temperature oscillations connected to el Nino and el Nina. Heat  distribution changes in the Pacific Ocean are particularly striking and lead to fluctuations in the patterns of winds aloft in the Jet Stream.

text: Why would I just listen to the official schtick and ignore the thousands of independent scientists who decry the AGW theme ? It wasn't more than a day after I posted my first Search results ( I blog but  the page is defunct as it was in Opera Community ) on the topic that I had a bunch of controversy to consider. A fellow member  ( a physicist ) encouraged me to look at info on YouTube disputing the 'science' and continue to explore. I did - with a vengeance - remembering the representations of a couple of futurists in a proper SF novel. That would be worldbuilding written in the Campbellesque tradition of consistent with known science. But that's the thing. Anybody familiar with the exercise known as speculative fiction knows its parameters and shortcomings. AGW fits like a glove. There is zero data confirming the speculation - but a whole lot of howling that doubt is disloyal. You are correct. I disagree enthusiastically that any of it is proven beyond a shadow of a doubt. That's because I cannot find any proof whatsoever. Nor am I likely to find any on events that have not occurred.
author: John Farnham

text:
John Farnham The whole point of a peer review process is for other scientists who are specialised in your field to check and critique your  theory so that you can improve it. There is nothing gained by waving 
 your theories in front of a YouTube comment section who knows very little about the topics you are talking about. This is just an childish exercise in inflating your own ego.

You are clearly an intelligent person who is not afraid to go against the status quo which is admirable. Some of the best scientists have gone against the status quo and this hasn't always been successful (Boltzmann and Galileo are good examples) But time favours the correct science. Your best hope is to improve your theory and publish it in a reputable journal so that others can learn from it.

I would be willing to believe your theories once they have been properly published and critiqued. Until then, this whole thing is a futile attempt.

text:
Global Warming is happening.

The current warming trend is of particular significance because most of it is extremely likely (greater than 95 percent probability) to be the result of human activity since the mid-20th century and proceeding at a rate that is unprecedented over decades to millennia.

Earth-orbiting satellites and other technological advances have enabled scientists to see the big picture, collecting many different types of information about our planet and its climate on a global scale. This body of data, collected over many years, reveals the signals of a changing climate.

The heat-trapping nature of carbon dioxide and other gases was demonstrated in the mid-19th century. Their ability to affect the transfer of infrared energy through the atmosphere is the scientific basis of many instruments flown by NASA. There is no question that increased levels of greenhouse gases must cause the Earth to warm in response.

Ice cores drawn from Greenland, Antarctica, and tropical mountain glaciers show that the Earth‚Äôs climate responds to changes in greenhouse gas levels. Ancient evidence can also be found in tree rings, ocean sediments, coral reefs, and layers of sedimentary rocks. This ancient, or paleoclimate, evidence reveals that current warming is occurring roughly ten times faster than the average rate of ice-age-recovery warming.

Source NASA: https://climate.nasa.gov/evidence/ (read more)

text: Erock Stoenescu Studies have shown that you're wrong though. Global warming is when greenhouse gases reflect the heat that would normally leave our atmosphere at a constant rate. That heat travels back to the surface of the Earth and warms it. Global warming is NOT the Earth's atmosphere getting hotter, it's the surface. Because all this extra energy is floating around, global warming is a direct cause to major climate change. The ice age is completely irrelevant to what is occurring now. What happened then was due to tectonic plates. The major weather now is due to humans. Hence why we have bigger hurricanes, springs of snow, and winters of sunshine and high temperatures, and extreme blizzards depending on your climate. That enough proof for global warming yet, or do you need a larger explanation to feed your ignorance?
